transcript.content: God! I don't believe this, one day he's got – Karl's really grumpy and all stressed cos he didn't have the record, we didn't wanna play, a rec- won't say it, we didn't wanna play a certain record he had lined up, cos it's rubbish.
I know, but you do this every week.
Cos it's... cos most of 'em are rubbish, that's why we choose...
But thirty seconds to go on the track and you're saying 'I don't wanna play that'.
And you're going 'oh stressing me out', you're meant to be at our beck and call we've, we've...
We've made you.
We've made you, we got you out the gutter and now you're getting- “Greatest Mind in the World" and all that.
That doesn't mean you can mess me about. If you were a doctor and you saved me life.
Yeah.
Right, there comes a point...
In a way, we have Karl.
Yeah.
Where were you going before we came alone...
Go on, what was he gonna say, what were you gonna say, he was gonna say something wise then?
No, I was gonna say, right, if, if, if you were a doctor and you saved me life, there's only so much, that I could give back to you, right.
Okay.
I can't...
What's unreasonable, what would be unreasonable?
Well you know.

Forget doctor, don't, no, no, no, no, cos that's its job right, supposing I just, I was just walking along and I saved your life, I gave you a kidney, or I, you know, resuscitated you or I dived into icy water, what, what, what could I hope from you then, before you start going 'hold on, hold on', what would you, what would you be willing to do for me until you sort of got, you lost your rag a little bit, cos I was asking too much.
So, what, didn't I know you before you've like, sorted a lung out for me?
No. I just gave you a lung, for example.
Well, I'd be a bit sort of, I'd be thinking why has he done that, if...
Suspicious!

But what I love though Rick is the idea of you, jumping into icy water to save someone, giving them a lung, I can guarantee if someone was lying on the floor screaming, they needed your help, you'd affect a foreign accent and go 'I no understand' and run off.
You know what he did once? Right, we went out a few weeks ago, right, and some woman had her handbag nicked, and she was all distressed, he said 'cha- chase the fella Karl'.
Steve chuckles.
You stood there...
Ricky laughs.
You, you pretended.
That's not true...
Let's be honest, look at Ricky...
That's not true.
...imagine Ricky chasing a criminal, look at his little legs, he'd never get anywhere.
He started to run and then he passed Starbucks or something and nipped in...
Ricky chortles.
For a short...
How did this turn on me? I'm a bad man, cos I don't give lungs away?
No, cos you don't chase criminals...
No-one would want my kidneys or my lungs for a start, I- I-, you know...
Did you chase the criminal, then?
No.
I did for a bit.
He walked.
No, you didn't did you?
No, I did a little bit, didn't I?
Yeah, we sort of spread out...
What...
...we missed him.
...where was it and what was the situation?
It was near...
Did you see a bag get snatched?
It was Carnaby Street.
No, she was crying and she was worried... some blokes came and sat next to her and just ran off with her purse and erm...
And you walked after them?

No, no they'd gone Steve, they'd they, I mean, yeah, they'd actually gone, it was just like a bit distressing, she was, she was devastated, I know how she feels as well, I had a jacket nicked and you think 'oh, I just gotta find 'em now'.
Yeah.
'Where are they, who...' you know, so she was really off her head with sort of like she was angry and sort of crying.
Yeah.
And it was horrible, it was horrible weren't it? Weren't it Karl?
He's broken his mike now.
Play a record.
Oh, play a record Karl...
This is pathetic.
...Karl, what are you doing mate, you just...
I don't believe this, there are only two weeks to go, these should be special.
Ricky pounds his fist on the desk for emphasis.
Karl, play the record, we've asked you to play the record.
'Bohemian Like You'.
Man alive!
Dandy Warhols - Bohemian Like You
Hives – Main Offender
Hives – Main Offender, on Xfm 104.9, I forgot to say who I was.
Go on who are you?
Ricky Gervais. Who are you?
Obviously. Steve Merchant.
And who's that little fella over there, little round fella.
Tiny little Karl Pilkington.
The funny little thing from the Smash adverts. Say “...and then they smash with them little knives...”, oh.
You do, yeah you're right, he does look like one of them.

He does, doesn't he, yeah, I was asking people if they've seen a rounder head than him, and that's the only one someone could come up with, that's the only thing they came up with. Oh look, oh look you're actually a little bit stressed now aren't you? Cos you had a drink last night, didn't ya?
I had a couple of drinks.
Yeah.
I was down at Steve's night.
Yeah.
He was doing a bit of DJing.
Yeah.
It went down a storm.
And that's why you're grumpy.
Shush, shush, shush, shush, did you hear what he just said? I was DJing last night, obviously at that Xfm evening.
Yeah, yeah.
Hour and a half, me and my friend split the time on the decks, what, what was the word you just used?
He went down a storm.
We went down a storm. Right, three girls, I was walking to the toilets during my set, three girls went 'you are a genius'...
Ricky giggles.
Right da-, whathisname, Dane Bowers... Zane Lowe?
What cos you played records in a certain order?
Yes.
Ricky laughs contemptuously.
Sorry Rick if you can't deal with that, sorry if you're a little bit jealous, because this time you can't share the award, alright?
Oh dear.
But it was my credit this time.
You can tell he hasn't been a DJ, because it's not just about...
It's not just about the songs you play, it's the way you play them.
Oh yeah...
The way you play them...whether it's 33 or 45, very important.
Yeah! Yeah! Leave your hand on them...
Exactly.
...as they try and go round.

But, er, but, three girls there, charmed by me, they loved it, er, Zane Lowe Xfm DJ and MTV presenter, probably one of the coolest blokes alive, he came up – gave us massive respect, he said 'i'm loving your set', he actually used those words, right, there were people coming up, couldn't believe their luck, it was roaring, we'd stick on a track, people would cheer as it came one, right, our particular favourite, Karl I'll think you'll agree, my particular triumvirate LL Cool J, 'Mama Said Knock You Out', leading straight into House of Pain 'Jump Around', then straight into the current Elvis track that's been re-released, remixed by Junkie XL, I played the original, which I'd already played on XFM before, I'm already there, cutting edge.
Yeah.
Right.
What, three old tracks you mean.
Three old tracks.
In a row?
Yep... and, er, I think the words that would best sum it up, are 'I kicked ass'.
Great.
Rick, alright.

Well, I'm gonna be kicking some arse today, because I'm gonna be shamelessly self-indulgent and we've only got two shows to go, so I'm playing some of the most beautiest tunes in the world, I was just telling Karl I've lined up a Simon and Garfunkel track 'Only Living Boy In New York', he went 'why's he the only living boy in New York?', I went 'what?', he went 'what does that mean then?' I went 'I don't know' he went 'well what's it about?', I said 'I don't, don't care, it's a lovely song' he said 'but, no, what's it about' I said 'I don't go into that', I said, he went 'I like, I like a story' I said 'like what'? He said 'Killing of Georgie – no trickery'.
Steve laughs.
Killing of Georgie. I think we should play that at the last...
It's good I heard it the other day on Radio 2, it was cracking.
Yeah?
It stands up well.
It's really good.
Tell 'em what it's about again.
It's about, um, a little girl- (clears his throat) a little gay fella.
A little what, a little gay fella?
Yeah.
Right.
Who, erm, I mean I haven't heard it for a bit, it's all off memories, but, erm, gay bloke, is he from Scotland?
I have... no idea.
He's from somewhere, where gays aren't liked.
Okay.
No, no, no.
No, he is.

'Georgie boy was gay I guess, nothing more and nothing less, the kindest guy I ever knew', right, now all he did was, right, his father said 'how can my son not be straight?' and kicked him out, right, goes to America...
Yeah, yeah, but you can handle all that, you can handle your dad not getting on with ya, if other people around ya are into the same scene.
Yeah? That's right.
But he was left on his own, he didn't know what to do.
Yeah.
He was getting stressed out.
Yep.
So he goes.
This was before like, before, I mean this was, when did this record come out?
Seventy...
Must be Seventies.
...seven.
77, yeah something like that.
Right.
And he's...
During punk.
Right, oh I see, yeah.
So he...
So, you know, The Village People had come along and made gay cool.
Yeah.
That had already happened, but it wasn't respected.
But he was watching the telly or something and he saw the New York had loads of them over there all having a good time...
No, no sorry, at no point in the song, does Rod Stewart say little, little gay Georgie was watching telly, and saw loads of gays in New York, at no point in that song.
But, this is what I like about that song, you can sort of picture what's going on.
You make it up.
A moment of contemplation.
Yeah.
Okay, so, so the little gay fella was watching telly, and there was, there was a presumably a, the “and now from New York - the gay show” yeah?
or whatever, cos it was a big scene over there in the seventies.
Yeah, okay, go on.
So he, er, goes over there, and he's having a great time and that, he's meeting...
“...went to New York town, very quickly settled down and soon became the toast of the great white way”
Yeah, they loved him.
“...all the old queens blew a fuse.”
Yeah.
Yeah.
And he, I don't know, he was out late one night...
Yeah.
...and he's walking home.
Yep.
And, er, gets attacked, gets killed.
Yeah.
And he's lying in...
“They didn't intend to take his life, they just pushed their luck a little too far that night.” Yeah, you see.
So, but what's good there, is it good that he had a bit of a good life, and was able to be himself.
Yep.
...or should he have stayed in Scotland?
He didn't come from Scotland, again, I've really...

I think, is there anyway we can get this song before the end of the show, and play it, cos I've, I've heard it recently, but a lot of people listening will have never heard this song, they won't have any idea what we're talking about.
Can I, Can I say what you said, when we were talking about that song, once, before?
Is it bad?
It might, it might be. Cos we were talking about you know, Georgie boy getting... and he you know, I don't know.
What?
It's when you said...
Ricky mouths something to Karl.
Well, it's a fact! I don't think if anyone...
Right, he said, so 'Killing of Georgie', he gets out, he dies, right, he goes 'well they do go out late...'
Steve hoots.
I know...
Gay people... go out late?

I've seen gay people and they start to party late on, that's why, in Soho right, girlfriend got in a cab right, Suzanne was in a cab and the cab driver, was taking her to an early start, right, she works at the BBC, early start, 4 in the morning, it was going down, it was mental in Soho at 4 in the morning, they were all still like star- starting the night out...
How d'you know, how do you know they were gay?
It's Soho, innit.
Fair enough.
Okay.
Play a track, we have to try and dig this out.
Yeah we well, this is Simon and Garfunkel, 'The Only Living Boy In New York', it's, it's lovely.
Simon and Garfunkel – The Only Living Boy In New York
'Only Living Boy In New York', do you like that?
It's got a nice feel to it.
Simon and Garfunkel.
Yeah.

Lovely, erm, bit later on I'm gonna be playing a Cat Stevens track, it's one of the most beautiful tracks ever written, it's called 'Lilywhite' off 'Mona Bone Jakon', look forward to that, we've got Eminem coming up.
We have, we've got the new Eminem single as well and a big giveaway Rick lest we forget.
I think we should tell 'em what that is.
Do you think so.
Yeah, well, we all went to the Baftas, as you know and we thought we could get a good prize out of this, so we got some celebs...
Yes.

...to sign, the Bafta bag they give away, it's just a nice, it's just a big sort of chunky cardboard carrier bag, you know, it's not the value that counts, this is what values it read out the sort of names we've got Steve.

These are the kind of celebrities that have signed these bags, obviously us three, plus Graham Norton, Angus Deayton signed it, Alan Davies – Johnathan Creek, Jamie Theakston, Paul Whitehouse, a lot of comedians you'll notice, Helen Baxendale from Cold Feet, who's also been in Friends, right, er, I don't know why that's so exciting, Steve 'Phil Mitchell' McFadden.
Yeah.
It's an eclectic bag, I notice actually that Steve's signature also mentions, I think he says Steve aka Phil Mitchell, which is very nice of him.
Yeah.
Peter Davidson, former, er, former Dr. Who.
I noticed also, that when you gave him the pen to sign it, he put the pen away.
Yeah he pocketed it.
I wanted to say, wh-wh-wh-wh-wh-whoa, whoa whoa...
Just his wily cockney ways.
...you're not Phil Mitchell now mate.
Exactly.
Give us the pen back.
Exactly. Simon Pegg and of course one of broadcasting's biggest legends Steve Wright.
Oh Steve Wright, yeah.
Got him to sign it as well. But you know, you're not gonna find that, that's quite an eclectic and kooky mixture of celebrity names.
Yeah.
You know, autographs on one bag.
And maybe we'll photocopy it and if you can't make out...
Just explain who they are...
...just explain who they are.

We can give that away, and, er, you know it's a little commemorative thing from the Baftas, there's a big Bafta logo on there and everything, it's pretty classy, I, did I mention this that our agent, who was there, he ran round getting a few of these autographs and I think, Helen Baxendale and a few people and went up to 'em and told them it was for charity... and that was why they signed it.
Karl gasps.
Which I think is a little bit cheeky, but that's what agents are like Karl! You've gotta understand that.
But, then again he didn't get anything from them, it's not like he said give us a pound
No, he just got signatures.
He just got their signature.
Well, he said that as well.
(Laughing) Did he? He made 42 quid.
Yeah, exactly.
They take a short respite while Ricky laughs.
Erm, but, err, so anyway, we're gonna give that away, we'll, we'll explai-
Is that a good prize? I think that's a nice prize, isn't it? It's a little commemorative thing...
Karl! You're turning your nose up at it.
No, it's, it's alright, I wouldn't want it.
Oh chri-, doesn't he, do people get you to sort of do campaigns on the radio, like “Drink Fosters – I wouldn't, you can...”
I notice on the big board here, it tells us that you can win signed and framed Chemical Brothers' Album covers on Sunday, that's just two geeks who've signed that, we've got like...
We've got three... alone, in this room.
Exactly, plus, we've got some of Britain's, you know the cream of Britain's light entertainment that have signed that bag, I'm just...
No, no, no it's good...
...appalled by you, that you're just so disrespectful of us.
No, but it's like, look how, when I went to the Bafta's with you and I wasn't really enjoying it.
I can't!! He's a ...!
What?! You didn't tell us this.
You're such an ungrateful...
There are so many people...
You're like a little charity case, you're like, oh...
I had chicks queuing up around the block.
You'd usually have to... someone like you would have to write to 'Jim'll Fix It' or Esther Rantzen to get, to meet us sort of people, and now it's on your doorstep!

I'm amazed, that you didn't enjoy it, why didn't you enjoy it? You got to walk down the red carpet, you went in, there was George Best, one of your footballing heroes was there, a load of other big names, you sat there, you had prime position, you came backstage with a load of other big names, eh, you had a lovely bit of grub.

You were filming the thing for the DVD we're making, that's you, that's you the cameraman on the DVD and yet you think 'oh...' now you look grumpy cos you had a couple of pints, and you've, oh, can't believe it.
Tell us why you didn't enjoy it, cos the ceremony, what didn't you enjoy about that?
Silence.
It was interminable wasn't it?
Far too long.
Wasn't it awful?
Three...
Boring.
...hours.
Sorry. I thought you were gonna say something.
Really?
Some nervous giggling.
Three hours.
Yeah.
Erm, I mean, I suppose for you two, at least, you know, you were gonna get something.
Sure.
Yeah.
But with me, it's like, I mean, I've never graduated or anything, so...
Have you not?
I'm trying a think of a situation, basically I sat there for three hours, knowing that I'm not gonna get anything out of the night.
Yeah.
Right. Now...
Ricky giggles.
No-one told...
Sorry! When we invited you and you said 'yes', did you think you were up for an award?
No.
Steve hoots.

But I thought, I thought, we'd be sat round tables, having a nice bit of food, whilst people are going up there and winning awards, but three hours of the same thing, over and over again, if a film's three hours in the cinema, you go 'well it's long, but, you know, I wonder how it's gonna end', but this was just like the same thing over and over again, some guy going up, 'thanks a lot, cheers for the bit of brass' and then going down, sitting down, same thing over and over again. I wouldn't, honestly right, I'd say it was one of the worst things I've ever had to do.
Ricky and Steve laugh in shock.
Christ!
Blinking hell!!

No, I enjoyed the night afterwards, when we did have a bit of lamb and a bit of veg and that, that was alright, and I went home and I was happy, and I got the little freebie bag, that you're talking about, that we're givin' away, which wasn't much good stuff in it.
Oh...
Alright!!
...christ!
No, cos Suzanne...
What would you have done on that Saturday night?
Suzanne said...
What would you have done, on a Sunday night rather, what would you have done, had you been at home?
A quiet moment of contemplation.
I would have stayed in with Suzanne, right, watching telly, had a nice bit of pate on toast or something, cup of tea, watching 24, but instead I had to buy an expensive suit, so I didn't show you up.
Ricky stifles a laugh.
Jesus Christ.
Yeah, how much did you spend on your suit?
Well, in total, right, cos of you know, the shoes, and the suit and the shirt and the tie; it was about 600 quid.
Ricky and Steve explode with laughter.
That's the most expensive evening ever!
Well, that's what I'm saying to ya and the daft thing is it's dark in there, I don't know why you've got to wear a nice suit.
You can't wear a tracksuit for goodness sake!
He said “it's dark in there!”
No, just a shirt and that, it doesn't make you a better person, wearing a suit.
No. It doesn't make you a better person, no.
We're not claiming it made you a better person.
No, well, that annoyed me.
Yeah.

Erm, I mean it was an experience, that's why I went, cos, you think, if I didn't go, I would have said to you when you invited me, 'no Steve, I don't wanna go' I would never have known, right and I've, I've, that's my sort of thing in life, right, if something comes up, you should take it, even if you're not gonna like it, it's a bit of an experience.
You know what he said to me, I phoned him up, cos we had to meet up and obviously he had to pose as my gay lover...
Yeah.

...to get in right. What was it, you said something to me, like “I've bought a suit, I'm looking good”, he said “I'm looking good, people'll think how on earth did he end up with that good looking guy.”
So he got into the role!
Yeah.
He started...
...That was what he said to me.
He started getting into it!
Such an insult.
Play a record, Karl.
I must just say we've had an email from Darryl, all sorts of people have emailed in saying well done on the Baftas and well done on your Room 101, they really like it.
Thank you.
This one guy here, Darryl, says “Ricky, has your dad only got one demob suit?”
Ricky brays with laughter.
Cos I don't know if you've noticed but Ricky wears the same suit, every single time he appears on TV, cos he spent a fortune on it, getting it tailor-made.
I've only got one.
It's a good suit, and now he's wearing it all the time.
I know, I know, and it's winter as well and it's like pure wool so I'm sweating everywhere I go...anyway. Usually it's too much cheese.
I won't be buying another.
Uh?
I won't be buying another one?
Ever.
That's it.
Suzanne told me today, right, cos I've gone, I've handed it in today, to have the trousers turned up a bit...
Why?
Cos, it was a bit of a bodge job for the night.
Yeah.
Right.

It was just some pins holding it up the other night, but you didn't notice and I didn't tell ya, cos I thought you'd be getting on the stage and saying look at that freak over there, with his pants hemmed up.
Ricky laughs.
But I took it, I took it to the place to get it done, Suzanne tells me that I'm gonna start shrinking now, I'm getting to that age where you start getting smaller.
Ricky laughs uncontrollably.
I love that, that must have been a revelation to you and a worry, like “how small do you get?” “how small do you get?” Oh...
Right, what we playing now?
I thought we'd have a little bit of 'Mali Music'.
'Mali Music'?
Oh...
Okay, go on then.
Mali Music – Sunset Coming On
Badly Drawn Boy – Something To Talk About.

Badly Drawn Boy – 'Something To Talk About', it's a good job we've got something to talk about, cos we're DJs on XFM 104.9, I'm Ricky Gervais with me, Stephen Merchant, course there Karl Pilkington, how you doing?
Course, you must have been excited at the Baftas cos we did bump into Dr Fox.
Oh, yeah.
Pleased with that.
Yeah.
What was the challenge again? The challenge was, you had to shout 'foxy'.

Yeah, the challenge was, it's sort of like 'Jackass' but wimpy Jackass, Karl was our cameraman for the night, cos we're doing the making of, sort of, series two, where we've filmed ourselves sort of writing it and doing bits and pieces and going to awards and all that, and, er, it's on me, and my challenge, I think, was it me that set my own challenge?
I think you did.

I had to shout “foxy!” and get him over and I bottled out five times, I just thought, he was talking to someone and then I did it and it, where's the victory in that? I shouted 'Foxy' and he came over and went “alright” and I thought 'where's the victory?', Jackass, they dive off buildings and things.
I was a little bit taken aback though, cos even though he was joking and mucking around, he was swearing, you don't expect that from Foxy.
Oh, behave, he was off duty.
No, I mean he's more than welcome, you just don't expect him to, he seemed like a lovely bloke, though, but he has got an enormous head, I mean I'm not gonna...
But I've got a problem with that.
I'm not disrespecting him he's a lovely guy, but his head is huge.
But, it's in proportion with his big body though, he's a big, he's a chunky wombat of a man.
Fair enough.
So am I!
It was a problem getting him on, on screen.
Cos of the huge head?
Yeah, I was struggling.
Well, I know the Pop Idol people had worries about that, they had to get special lenses.
Yeah, yeah. I love the fact that us three freaks, can take the piss out of anyone.

Whoa, whoa, whoa, stop there though Rick, cos I was on TV briefly, there was a thing about The Office on Top Ten TV Bastards on Channel 4 and I appeared on there briefly talking about the show, and, erm, there's this girl who's girlfriend of a friend of mine and she's, she said “I saw you on TV last night”, I went 'yeah', she went  “I tell you this, you're better looking on TV than you are in real life and that's good for ya.” and I want, I went, I was like, I didn't know if that was a compliment, cos it's like...
Definitely not.
... well I'm not on TV, so it's not beneficial in any way.
Yeah and sooner or later you have to step out of the TV.
But that's like saying, I normally find you pretty repulsive, my opinion changed slightly last night cos you were on the box, but it didn't, it sounded like a compliment.
Through the aid of a different...
Through the aid of lighting, and appearing for 12 seconds on screen, in small doses...
Oh god.
She thought I wasn't as bad looking as I was in real life.
A lot of people have phoned in and have wondered if you are Morph grown up, because they've seen a picture of you on the website.
Do you mean, me or Karl?
Karl.
Right.
Yeah.
What d'ya mean?

No, cos people have seen you, next to a picture of Morph and it's exac- if you draw round, honestly Karl, if you lay you down and draw round you, it's exactly the same shape as Morph, or the Pillsbury Doughboy.
Or a gingerbread man.
Ricky laughs.
You do look like a gingerbread man, it's a great...
Oh I love, Karl, we think you're brilliant, we like looking at you, talking to you, hearing what you got to say, we think of you don't we, in the week sometimes.
Rick, I had a bit of good news this morning...
Go on.
And I don't mean this in any way, I'm sure it's an emotional thing for her, but in The Sun it says that Dido, her wedding's off...
Right.
..., just thinking 'ding-dong'...
Ricky chuckles.
...cos for some reason, I don't know what it is, I was having a chat with my mates, I've always been under the assumption I could pull Dido.
Because she's...
Because she's quite ordinary, d'you know what I mean, she looks a bit ordinary, she's quite an attractive woman but like in...
Would that be an opening chat up line.
'You look quite ordinary'.
“Dido, I don't think you could get anything better looking than me, because you're not too hot yourself”
Exactly...
“My name's Steve Merchant...”
...I'd wear a, actually what I'd do is go 'right, I'm not gonna meet you in the flesh, I'm gonna send a picture of me on video...'
Send a video...
'I look great.'
“This is me on Top TV Bastards, what do you think?”
See what you think.
“And if you think it's good, well I'm certainly no worse, without the lighting and make-up, so don't worry about that.”
Exactly.
Oh.
Oh, Dido.
Shall we have a little bit of Bowie? Shall we have a little bit of Bowie?
What's your thing about Dido, she's like a kind of, she's a bit like a receptionist...
Who got up and sang once, cos she you knows a few tunes...
At karaoke .
...and a bloke came up, “Er, hi, I'm, Gridling Records, I'm thinking of releasing a CD” and it just goes mental.
Exactly.
Everyone buys it.
It's good though innit.
But she should be doing photocopying or filing, do you not think? The way she looks, she's got that very kind of suburban look.
No, but the whole look thing annoys me, d'you know there's another Popstars thing starting.
Yeah.
It's going on in Ireland, apparently it's Ireland's version of it.
Okay.

And today, you saw all these kids like rushing in, fat ones there and ugly kids, and you're thinking it's sad and everything they might have a good voice, but they've no chance, right, and there was a woman there who looked a bit like Britney, and the bloke straight away before even hearing the voice - “Britney lookalike over there, go and get her in, give her a ticket, she's through to the next phase.” and it's just annoying, Dido isn't beautiful, but she's nice enough, d'you know what I mean?
Yeah, that's why she's fine for me, I mean, you know...
They don't all have to be stunning.
...my standards are quite low.
D'you think Steve should go out with her then? I mean, that's what we're asking ya, do you think he should?

I was picking at my food in the BBC canteen, and he went “right, right, I'm honestly thinking of stopping having lunch with you.” I went 'what?' he went “it winds me up” he said “it winds me up, it winds me up, you won't eat anything, it's a lovely bit of chicken there, you're not eating that, you're not eating that, it winds me up too much, like you get irritated by people, noise and that, you eating it just winds me up Gervais” and then he went “you're a cock.”

Yeah, it really annoyed me. His eating habits drive me mad. Cos he's constantly whinging about the fact that he thinks he's got cancer, every 25 seconds 'wait a minute, I got, I can feel a lump, I can feel a lump', “it's your cock”, 'no it's not, it wasn't there before, it wasn't there, it's a lump, it's a lump, I'm dying, I'm dying, I'm dying, quick to the hospital' I have been, how many times have you been to a doctor's clinic, and sat in the waiting room, right, Karl how many times have you been there with a friend of yours? Twice I've been with Ricky. One time when we were writing the 1st series of The Office, we were writing in the waiting room, for the doctor, cos he had to go in there, and have his, cos he thought he had testicular cancer.
Gervais explodes with laughter.
I swear to god.
I'd seen a thing about it.
He thought he had testicular cancer.
I just said, he put my mind, I never worry about that again, he said no you're not in the risk group and that, the other time was...
But, wait a minute...
The other time...
...he had to go in there...

The other time was I thought I had stomach cancer and I went, she went 'why?' I said “oh god...” and she said 'When you get a sore throat do you think you have throat cancer?', I said “I have thought that.” And she sort of, she sort of said get out or here you idiot, and that's what I like, I like that when they do that, but I think it's sort of since my mum died of it, and I just think 'oh god it's in the family', and that's the thing I worry about.
But, d'you prefer, I mean I don't go, cos it scares me, I prefer...
Yeah, I'm like that.

...I prefer not to go, cos he might, I always worry that, especially with cancer and things, that they'll go, you know, I'll go there with a sore leg or something and they'll go 'no, your legs fine, but look at this we've found in your head.'
Ricky laughs.
If it's a brain you'll be laughing!

No, but d'you know what I mean? They'll find something, cos none of us are perfect, and as you get older, you get little moles and stuff and they say 'oh we best get rid of that' it's like leave it alone, it's not causing any problems.
(Through an explosion of laughter) Imagine arguing! “That shouldn't be there.” 'Leave it alone, it's not...' “Well it is it's getting bigger and it's strangling your lungs.”

But Rick's sort of like, but my point was, this is what upsets me, he constantly worries about his health, he's constantly obsessed “I've found some buboes, I think I've got plague.” Every single, I mean every ten minutes, he's got something.
I started choking once, cos I swallowed some dust, didn't I?
Yeah, he swallowed some dust, he started choking, like he'd swallowed a fish bone, right, he was literally, I thought he was gonna die... from dust.

And he panicked, he shouted, right I'm choking, I'm going blue and I'm telling him hit me, and he's hitting me on the back, and he shouted 'I don't know the Heimlich Manoeuvre' and I was choking and dying, but then I wanted to laugh, cos he panicked, he was like if he's gonna die I want him to know that I didn't know the Heimlich Manoeuvre...
I did everything, I did everything I could, but I didn't know the Heimlich Manoeuvre, so that was why I couldn't have saved him.
Oh dear.
But my point is this, he worries about his health and yet he eats like a child, he eats crisps constantly, Coke, he keeps going, 'oh I got a headache, I got a headache', “drink some water”
Yeah.
'No, boring, hate it.'
'Boring', I do say that, yeah.

Chips, pizza, sausages; sausages, beans and chips, I've never seen someone eat so much sausage, I don't know how he's not bored of it yet. Sausage, chips, beans, everything's gotta have cheese on it, Parmesan cheese please, you know, on anything.

Why don't they leave it in a restaurant as well, seriously, why don't they leave the Parmesan cheese it's like it's gold dust or summat, salt, have as much salt as you want, but they, they come along, and I've found myself sneaking, I've said to Jane “look out is the waiter looking, and I've lent over, and did some more Parmesan and I've felt really guilty, just leave it.
It was on a trifle!
Ricky laughs.
You don't need cheese on dessert. I've explained it to you.
Oh dear.

It's just, so this is why, this is why I get angry, and that's why... and I tell you this, if I had to be, Ricky was on Room 101, if I had to be on there, I tell you this Ricky Gervais would be the first person in there, he'd be straight in there man, cos I got a list as long as your arm.
What did you think when I said annoying people making noises?

Unbelievable, it was so, yeah, you talked about annoying noises, and people that make noises that are annoying, he is the most irritating man I have ever met, I swear to god, I don't mean that as an insult, you really are, because you go out of your way to be insulting and irritating.
Thanks.
That's fine, but you know, you'd be straight in there.
Yeah.
In fact we should do this next week for Karl, we should draw up a list of Karl's hates, what he'd put in Room 101...
Oh, that is...
...think about that next week Karl.
...that is genius. Next week, so we've got the competition, we've got Karl, I'll tell you what let's play a record, and do White Van Karl.
Yeah.
Let's slam dunk this mother.
(Chortling) That's true enough.
What you gonna play?
Some Alpine Stars.
Alpine Stars – Carbon Kid.
Alpine Stars – 'Carbon Kid', featuring little Brian from Placebo.
Oh yeah.
I thought I recognised him. Yeah, it's alright that. Right, White Van Karl – Karl -Karl.
Steve does sound effects.

White Van Karl, - yeah this is where we steal the White Van Man column from The Sun, and basically fire those questions at Karl, getting his opinions on the week's news, okay Karl, let me see, let me see, let me see, okay what do you make of this, the average woman, apparently takes 27 minutes to go out, did you know that?
Are they saying that's a good thing or...
No, they're saying the bare minimum it takes...
No, average surely?
No, no, no but I remember reading, I'm sure they said it takes them 27 minutes to get ready to go out at the very least I think.
It's not that bad if it's for a night out, it's, that's, I mean 30 minutes is alright...
But if it's going to get 20 Woodbines.
But...yeah, or you know if the house is on fire and it's like quick get ready and get out.
I don't think it's in a, in a fire, no. I think, go on...
I think twent- that's alright...
Twenty minutes is alright.
How long do you take?
I take about 27 minutes.
I can take up to that.
But do they include the getting up, and having a bath, all that.
It doesn't give me any more details.
No?
27 minutes...
That's difficult to go by. Difficult to go on, that one.
How long does Suzanne take to go out the house?
Depends, like I say, if we're just nipping out, just shopping...
The old flip flops and trackies on.
Yeah, but going out takes a bit longer don't it.
Yeah.
Yeah you gotta iron the trackies.
Yeah, yeah, yeah.
Good one.
Okay, erm, another one, I really don't know what the ins and outs of this story are, Sven-Goran Eriksson sticking with Nancy rather than Ulrika.
Well, it's his wife innit, or his girlfriend.
Yeah, I don't know even if this story's true, no-one seems to have offered any evidence for it.
Anyway, move on.
Everyone's remained silent.
It's rubbish.
And, er, what do you make of this, David Beckham was driving despite having an injured foot, and just further threatening his World Cup chances. Now obviously you're a big football fan.
Well, not that big, I like the odd game.
Sure.
Would that hurt him, would that hurt his foot?
It can't be good for him.
It's not in a plaster, it's not in a big cast is it?
Surely it's better to drive, than it is to walk on it.
Good point.
Fair enough. Can't argue with that.
Can't get the bus can he?
What do you make of this fascist leader who's having a lot of success in the French Presidential elections?
What's he doing?
Have you not, have you not come across this story?
No.
Right, this is one of the big big political stories.
He's far right and he's got nearly 20 percent, in one of the...
He's a Far Right, fascist leader and he's having considerable success in the French elections.
I don't think we should be asking Karl questions like this.
You've got...
I'm getting scared.
There's all sorts of bad stuff going on in the world that we don't know about.
Yeah.
Well, we know about this.
Ricky explodes with laughter.
Yeah, but you're better off not knowing, cos there's nothing I can do about it.
Ricky and Steve laugh.
You're absolutely right Karl, fair enough. Can't argue with that. Oh god, man alive.
That's fantastic. That is brilliant.
Have we got it, have we got it lined up.
Bit of Rolling Stones.

It's the one song I've been wanting to play since we've been on Xfm really, and took me a while to track it down, obviously in the Xfm library, but here it is, 'Gimme Shelter' from The Rolling Stones.
It's an amazing track.
The Rolling Stones - Gimme Shelter
'Gimme Shelter' from The Rolling Stones.
(DJ voice) Surely if there was a soundtrack to the Vietnam War, that would be on there, wouldn't it.
Steve hoots.

Can I just reiterate this giveaway then, we've got this bag signed by a number of celebrities, Graham Norton, Angus Deayton, different people on there, and if you want to win that, you have to email or write in, with what you are willing to swap, okay, so you need to swap something, and something which will enhance Karl's life, could be anything, you could have made, you could have bought it. Anything, but you have to have it, you can to send it to us in exchange for this signed bag and you can email Karl, Karl.Pilkington, Karl with a 'K', [email protected], or you can write to 'The Bag' or 'Ricky Gervais' Big Bag.'
I just realised why you've been saying Karl with a 'K', cos you can have Carl with a 'C', can't you.
Yes you can.
As in Cox.
Absolutely. You can write to Xfm P.O. Box 104.9, 104.9? 1049, London WC2 H7XX, alright.
Okay?
Right.
Alright?
Well, there's gonna be a bit of a change, isn't there?
Yes, that's absolutely right Ricky, normally...
We've decided just...
...we'd end the show with a Song For The Ladies.
...but, because it's sort of Karl's penultimate show and we're gonna play one of his favourite tracks, what are you gonna...
I just thought we could play, this, it is obviously 'The Killing of Georgie'...
By Rod Stewart.
...by Rod Stewart and this is a Song For The Gays.
Ricky giggles.

In these days of changing ways, so called liberated days, a story comes to mind of a friend of mine.Georgie boy was gay I guess, nothin' more or nothin' less, the kindest guy I ever knew.His mother's tears fell in vain, the afternoon George tried to explain, that he needed love like all the rest.Pa said there must be a mistake, how can my son not be straight, after all I've said and done for him
See his father, took it as a sort of  personal sleight, but you can't help it, you know.
It's not his fault.
And as he said, he's just gay, it doesn't make him a nasty person.
Not at all.
Leavin' home on a Greyhound bus, cast out by the ones he loves, a victim of these gay days it seems.
Are you enjoying this Karl?
Yeah, but, I'm not gay.
No evidence of him being Scottish.
No, but...

Georgie went to New York town, where he quickly settled down and soon became the toast of the great white way.Accepted by Manhattan's elite, in all the places that were chic, no party was complete without George.Along the boulevards he'd cruise and all the old queens blew a fuse. Everybody loved Georgie boy
When he says they blew a fuse, they're not electricians, he's sort, sort of...
And it's not a euphemism either.
Ricky giggles.

The last time I saw George alive, was in the summer of seventy-five, he said he was in love, I said I'm pleased.George attended the opening night of another Broadway hype, but split before the final curtain fell.Deciding to take a short cut home, arm in arm they meant no wrong, a gentle breeze blew down Fifth Avenue
Oh, I'm worried.
I'm a bit edgy, he's out late.
I know, and he's taken a shortcut, which is mental.
Not in New York City.
Yeah.
He doesn't know the area, he's from Scotland.

Out of a darkened side street came a New Jersey gang, with just one aim to roll some innocent passer-by.There ensued a fearful fight, screams rang out in the night, Georgie's head hit a sidewalk cornerstone.
I bet it was them that was screaming.
Yep.

A leather kid, a switchblade knife, he did not intend to take his life, he just pushed his luck a little too far that night.The sight of blood dispersed the gang, a crowd gathered, the police came, an ambulance screamed to a halt on Fifty-third and Third.
I'm suddenly worried, this isn't a true story is it?
Who knows?
If it is, we don't know that, I just wanted to say that, we're not, that'd be terrible.
Yeah.

Georgie's life ended there, but I ask who really cares, George once said to me and I quote: he said "Never wait or hesitate, get in kid, before it's too late, you may never get another chance, 'Cos youth's a mask but it don't last, live it long and live it fast." Georgie was a friend of mine.
See, how come you think this might be a true story?
I just got, I just got suddenly worried then.
No, but how can this be a true story and the bloke jumping out of a window and hearing his phone ringing...
No, but Rod Stewart, I just suddenly thought, what if he's written a song about this, and this bloke did actually exist and was killed, and I started panicking?
Yeah...
I don't think it is, is it?
I'm almost certain it's not.
Okay.
Is that it then?
Is that it then, have we gotta pack up and go home?
Hmm.
Yeah? Well I think we've enjoyed ourselves.
I've loved it, I loved every minute of it.
[email protected] for your suggestions as to what you're willing to swap for the signed bag, see you next week.
Bye.
